title: Data & Methods
text:
2. Methods

2.1 Preprocessing and integration
Key steps: - Cleaning and standardising IDs (tract GEOID, facility IDs) - Merging hospital, buffer hospitals, and community health centers into one supply layer - Validating population counts (ACS baseline, WorldPop cross-check) - Constructing SVI and Medicaid-related indicators


2.2 Network analysis and accessibility modelling

2.2.1 Analytical pipeline



2.2.2 Baseline drive time and the edge-effect problem




2.2.3 Intermediate process checks






2.3 Machine learning clustering and neighborhood typologies
Using KMeans clustering from scikit-learn, tract-level indicators are clustered into interpretable neighborhood types.

2.3.1 Clustering diagnostics and visuals




2.3.2 Typology legend used in final maps

title: About
text:
Author: Haolong Chen
Program: Master of City Planning, Smart Cities concentration
Institution: University of Pennsylvania
This site is the final project for MUSA 5500 and also forms the empirical core of a broader thesis on healthcare accessibility and equity in Philadelphia.

title: About
text:
Purpose
The project demonstrates how network-based accessibility models and equity metrics can be combined to diagnose where acute-care access is structurally limited, quantify the Medicaid equity gap, and propose priority locations for new or expanded facilities.

title: About
text:
Technical stack
Python libraries, GeoPandas, Pandas, NumPy, OSMnx, NetworkX, Rasterio, scikit-learn, hvPlot, Holoviews, Panel.
Visualization, Bokeh tiles and Carto basemaps for web-native maps.
Deployment, Panel exported HTML embedded into a Quarto multi-page website, served via GitHub Pages.

title: About
text:
Disclaimer
This is a student research project, not an official product of the City of Philadelphia, the University of Pennsylvania, or any healthcare provider.

title: Beyond Distance: Spatial Accessibility and Equity of Healthcare During COVID-19
text:
Author: Haolong Chen
Course: UPenn MUSA 5500 Geospatial Data Science in Python
Date: December 12, 2025

title: Beyond Distance: Spatial Accessibility and Equity of Healthcare During COVID-19
text:
Live Website (Main Panel Site)
Main interactive dashboard (original Panel export):
https://chenhl0503-create.github.io/philly-healthcare-accessibility/

This Quarto website is an additional multi-page documentation site that embeds the exported deliverables and figures.

title: Beyond Distance: Spatial Accessibility and Equity of Healthcare During COVID-19
text:
Project Overview
COVID-19 acted as a stress test for urban healthcare systems. When mobility is restricted, traditional metrics such as “20-minute driving catchments” become unrealistic for low-income, carless, and essential workers.
This project investigates the Philadelphia Paradox: a city with world-class hospitals (Penn, Jefferson) that still suffers from severe health disparities by neighborhood and race. Moving beyond simple Euclidean distance, the analysis uses an Enhanced Two-Step Floating Catchment Area (E2SFCA) model to quantify the gap between:

Theoretical access: all hospitals reachable on a driving network

Actual access: the subset of facilities that accept Medicaid, for socially vulnerable populations

title: Beyond Distance: Spatial Accessibility and Equity of Healthcare During COVID-19
Beyond Distance: Spatial Accessibility and Equity of Healthcare During COVID-19
References
text: The full thesis engages with over 200 academic and policy sources. Below are the core methodological references that anchor the models and interpretations shown in this site.

title: References
text:
Key methodological references

CDC. (2020). Delay or Avoidance of Medical Care Because of COVID-19–Related Concerns. MMWR Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report.
Luo, W., & Qi, Y. (2009). An enhanced two-step floating catchment area (E2SFCA) method. Health & Place.
Wang, F. (2012). Measurement, optimization, and impact of health care accessibility: A methodological review. Annals of the AAG.
Planey, A. M., et al. (2022). Locating equity: Spatial access and health equity analysis of the Medicaid-accepting safety-net. Social Science & Medicine.
Roy, A., & Kar, B. (2022). A multicriteria decision analysis framework to measure equitable healthcare access during COVID-19.
Faraji-Najarkolaie, F., et al. (2022). Expanding vulnerability indices for pandemic effects. Journal of Transport & Health.

Etc, additional sources are cited in the written paper but omitted here for brevity.

title: References
text:
Data sources

U.S. Census Bureau, ACS 5-year estimates (2021)
CDC / ATSDR Social Vulnerability Index (SVI)
OpenDataPhilly and state health sources for hospitals
City of Philadelphia and health department pages for community health centers
HUD Qualified Census Tracts (QCT)
OpenStreetMap via OSMnx
WorldPop raster grids
